description: Jotto is a word guessing game similar to Mastermind. The player must guess a five-letter word. The player can type in a word each turn after which the computer will tell the number of correct letters in the correct locations (jots). The goal is to guess the mystery word in as few turns as possible.
title: Jotto

description: Diddle is a puzzle game for the Altair 8800. It doesn't use a monitor and is played entirely on the address lights on the computer. A moving light pattern is visible on the LEDs and it's up to the player to find out the switches that need to be turned on and off to make it come to a halt. It can be played at higher speeds for higher difficulty.
title: Diddle

description: Life in Full Color is a color graphics version of Conway's Game of Life. Running on an Altair 8800 or IMSAI 8080 requires the TV Dazzler peripheral to run in color graphics on a TV screen.
title: Life in Full Color

description: Kill the Bit is a reflex game for the Altair 8800 that doesn't require a screen. A bit cycles through the upper eight address lights on the machine and players must use their reflexes to "kill" it by toggling the switch at its location at just the right moment. Hitting a switch at the wrong moment creates another bit that needs to be destroyed. The player wins when no bits are left.
title: Kill the Bit

description: A Musical Number Guessing Game is a simple number guessing game where the Altair 8800 thinks of a number and the player must guess which. After each guess, the lights on the computer will indicate if the value was too high (all lights go on), or too low (all lights go off). When the correct number is guessed the game will play "Daisy", which requires a transistor radio to be hooked up to the Altair 8800.
title: A Musical Number Guessing Game

description: Tiny Trek is an adaptation of Star Trek, written in TinyBASIC and condensed in a form to work on an 8K Altair 8800. The basics of the game remain the same. Controlling a Federation starship the player must rid the galaxy of Klingons.
title: Tiny Trek

description: Another Tiny Trek is version of Star Trek written in MITS BASIC. It is based on the FORTRAN program that lived on the Mainframe of the University of Texas. Like other variants the player takes control of a Federation ship and must try to rid the galaxy of Klingons. There are 20 different commands available.
title: Another Tiny Trek

description: Chase is a simple action game for one or two players. A bouncing dot moves across the screen and the players are tasked to try and catch it. The game requires a video display.
title: Chase

description: Dazzler Tic Tac Toe is a simple Tic-Tac-Toe game, but using the Cromemco TV Dazzler displays custom graphics on TV. The game plays as expected, where the player must beat the computer by getting three in a row.
title: Dazzler Tic Tac Toe

description: Backgammon allows players to play the classic board game on an Altair 8800 with TV Dazzler.
title: Backgammon

description:
33 Programs and Projects for the Altair 8800 is a book with various information for Altair 8800 owners. There are also some games included:

  • Pong - Allow playing of a Pong variant using an oscilloscope plotter.
  • Tic Tac Toe - a computer implementation of the classic pen and paper game.
title: 33 Programs and Projects for the Altair 8800

description: Chase! is a two-player chasing game that uses the TV Dazzler to show graphics on a TV. One player must chase the other. Vertical bars move downward into the playspace and must be avoided. The players use joysticks to move.
title: Chase!

description: Track is a simple game in which a spiral is displayed on the screen and the player must draw a line from the outside of the screen to the center without touching the spiral's line.
title: Track

description: Card Game is a computer adaptation of Las Vegas-style Blackjack written in BASIC for the Altair 8800.
title: Card Game

description: Tic-Tac-Toe is a digital version of the classic pen and paper game. The player and computer take turns putting their marks on the grid. This Altair 8800 implementation doesn't use a screen and instead displays all information on the memory LED lights and takes input directly from the switches. The computer is always first and plays a perfect game, so never loses.
title: Tic-Tac-Toe

description: Blackjack is a computer implementation of the classic card game. The game is written in BASIC specifically for the Altair 8800 and comes with full instructions. The player must draw cards and get as close to a value of twenty-one without getting busted. If the computer gets closer he wins the round.
title: Blackjack

description: Roulette is a simulation of the casino gambling game of the same name. The game is written in BASIC. The player can bet on a number and hope the result comes up.
title: Roulette

description: Dice Game plays a game of dice on a basic Altair 8800. Little is known about the actual game, most likely it simulates Craps.
title: Dice Game

description: Lunar Lander is a simple text-based variant of Lunar Lander. The player must try to land a lunar landing module on the moon keeping into account fuel, velocity, and distance to the surface. The game is written in BASIC.
title: Lunar Lander

description: Number Guessing Routine is a number guessing game played on the front panel of the Altair 8800. The computer has a number in mind and the player uses the switches to guess for a number. The computer will indicate using the led lights if it's correct, high or low.
title: Number Guessing Routine

description: Ping Pong is a very simplistic Pong variant played on the front panel of an Altair 8800. The ball is represented by a lit LED on the front panel and the player must bounce it back by flipping the switch at its location at exactly the right moment. Since there's only one row of LEDs it's a single-dimensional version of Pong.
title: Ping Pong

description: Stock Market Simulation allows up to 10 players to compete in a stock market simulation. Players can buy and sell stock in an attempt to make a profit.
title: Stock Market Simulation

description: Number Guessing Game has the player guess a number between 0 and 255. Requires a TVT-II (Television Typewriter) as input.
title: Number Guessing Game

description: Lunar Lander is one of multiple text-based variants of Lunar Lander. The player must try to land a lunar landing module on the moon keeping into account fuel, velocity, and distance to the surface. The game is written in BASIC.
title: Lunar Lander

description: Rocket is one of many text-based variants of Lunar Lander for the Altair 8800. The player must try to land a lunar landing module on the moon keeping into account fuel, velocity, and distance to the surface. The game requires the TVT-II teletype as an input device.
title: Rocket

description: Lunar Landing Game is a more extended variant of Lunar Lander for the Altair 8800. The player must try to land a lunar landing module on the moon keeping into account fuel, velocity, and distance to the surface. The game is written in BASIC.
title: Lunar Landing Game

description: This Tic-Tac-Toe game uses heuristics to let the AI learn to play the game better with every consecutive game. The rules remain the same with the player and AI taking turns to place their mark on a three by three grid in an attempt to get three in a row.
title: Tic-Tac-Toe

description: Star Trek is one of many versions of Star Trek for the Altair 8800. It is written in BASIC. Like other variants the player takes control of a Federation ship and must try to rid the galaxy of Klingons.
title: Star Trek

description: Numguess is a simple number guessing game written in Altair BASIC.
title: Numguess

description: Catch is a game in which the player must chase the computer on a 5 by 5 board. The game is written in BASIC.
title: Catch

description: Reaction is a simple game to test the player's reaction time. The player must press a terminal key when the computer rings a bell. The time between the bell and the button press is displayed. The game is written in Altair BASIC.
title: Reaction

description: Missle Plane (sic) is a two-player game written in BASIC. One player controls a plane and the other must try to shoot down the plane with a missile.
title: Missle Plane

description: Yum is a digital version of Yahtzee for the Altair 8800. The game is written in BASIC and all the prompts and documentation are in French.
title: Yum

description: Target is a game of skill in which the player must fire missiles at a moving target. The target moves along the right side of the screen. Missiles take time to travel the screen so the player must lead the target in order to hit. The score displayed on the screen increases for targets hit.
title: Target

description: Number Predictor is a number guessing game on the Altair 8800. The game is written in Altair BASIC. The player must try to guess the number chosen by the computer.
title: Number Predictor

description: Guess 1 is one of two random number guessing games for the Altair 8800 written by Jim Salem.
title: Guess 1

description: Guess 2 is one of two random number guessing games for the Altair 8800 written by Jim Salem.
title: Guess 2

description: TTT 3D is a three dimensional version of Tic-Tac-Toe. The game plays identical to normal Tic-Tac-Toe, with the player and computer taking turns to place their mark on a grid, but now there's an additional dimension to the grid. The game is written in BASIC.
title: TTT 3D

description: Qubic is a digital implementation of the three-dimensional Tic-Tac-Toe variant for the Altair 8800. The player plays against the computer, putting their marks in a 4x4x4 grid with the aim of getting four in a row.
title: Qubic

description: Horse Racing is a horse betting game for the Altair 8800. The game is written in Altair BASIC. The aim of the game is to win virtual money by betting on horse races.
title: Horse Racing

description: Wampus is a Hunt the Wumpus variant. The player must hunt a Wampus which is hiding in a dodecahedron maze of 20 cave-like rooms. The player can be attacked by the Wampus monster, super bats and die from bottomless pits.
title: Wampus

description: Bowl is a bowling simulation for up to four players. 10 frames of bowl are played. There is very little skill involved and most of the game is based purely on luck and random number generation. After each ball is thrown the status of the pins is displayed.
title: Bowl

description:
Game of Life is an implementation of Conway's Game of Life for the Altair 8800. The player can draw patterns and watch how they evolve based on the simple rules of Conway's Game of Life.

  • Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbours dies, as if caused by under-population.
  • Any live cell with two or three live neighbours lives on to the next generation.
  • Any live cell with more than three live neighbours dies, as if by overcrowding.
  • Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbours becomes a live cell, as if by reproduction.
title: Game of Life

description: Hangmath is a Hangman variant with a twist. Instead of guessing for a word, a sum is displayed, but all the numbers are blanked out. To get started the player can reveal all numbers in a single column and make one free guess for another number. After that each incorrect guess counts and when the sum is revealed the player is graded on how well he or she did.
title: Hangmath

description: Injun Poker is a digital implementation of the Indian Poker card game. Both players have a card but can only see the card of the other player. Each player must bet on whether their own hidden card is higher than the opponents. Each player starts out with 1000 beads. The player plays against the computer. Each turn the player can bet, call, drop or quit. The first player to lose all beads loses the game.
title: Injun Poker

description: Tic Tac is an implementation of the classic pen and paper game Tic-Tac-Toe. The player plays against the computer. Both take turns placing their mark in a three-by-three grid. The first player to get three in a row wins the game.
title: Tic Tac

description: Tic-Tac-Toe is an implementation of the classic pen and paper game of the same name. The player plays against the computer. Both take turns placing their mark in a three-by-three grid. The first player to get three in a row wins the game.
title: Tic-Tac-Toe

description: Audio Star Trek is a typical variant of the seminal Star Trek game. What sets it apart from other implementations is the addition of audio. Sounds are played when firing photon torpedoes, and phasers, when warping, on death, and with general input. The core of the game remains the same as other variants with the player controlling the Star Trek Enterprise and searching sectors and quadrants for Klingon cruisers which must all be destroyed without running out of shields or fuel.
title: Audio Star Trek

description:
Game of Life is an implementation of Conway's Game of Life written for the IMSAI 8080 (clone of the Altair 8800) in BASIC E. The player can draw patterns and watch how they evolve based on the simple rules of Conway's Game of Life.

  • Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbours dies, as if caused by under-population.
  • Any live cell with two or three live neighbours lives on to the next generation.
  • Any live cell with more than three live neighbours dies, as if by overcrowding.
  • Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbours becomes a live cell, as if by reproduction.

The game is designed to play on a teletype, so the player can fill in the paper size at the start.
title: Game of Life

description: Computer Football is an American football simulation game for one or two players (or a computer vs computer match). Players must select a defensive or offensive play on their turn. When playing with two players the play chosen can be obfuscated so that the other player doesn't know which play was chosen. Different combinations of plays will result in different outcomes which are displayed in text as the current time, ball position, down and yards to go.
title: Computer Football

description: Zapp the Moon Man is a simple action game in which a moon man moves across the screen. The player must fire a lightning bolt at the right time to zap it. There are limited lightning bolts to fire and the game keeps track of how many moon men have been zapped.
title: Zapp the Moon Man

description: Gomoku in BASIC is a Gomoku program programmed in BASIC. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid, however to fit the screen this implementation uses a smaller grid of 10x10. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game. Another change to the official rules is that rows of more than five pieces are also considered a win. The player plays against the computer.
title: Gomoku in BASIC

description: Star Chase is a Star Trek fan game. The player must defend a micro star from a Klingon vessel. The player cannot allow the Klingon or themselves to get too close to the star in sub-warp velocity as it will trigger its destruction. There are also black holes that must be avoided. The player wins if they can capture the Klingon ship.
title: Star Chase
